title: Mom who lost kids after her car swerved into path of truck sues driver for $10m
text:
Trista Curry, top right, has sued the driver of a truck who drove into the back of her car and killed her sons Maxwell and Camden (left), despite investigators clearing the trucker of any wrongdoing (Pictures: Sustad Photography/GoFundMe/KUTV)

A mother who lost her two young sons after her car swerved into the path of a truck traveling behind her has sued its driver for $10million.

Trista Curry lost control of her Honda Pilot moments before the March 2018 accident in Fargo, North Dakota – and has now sought to blame the truck driver for the tragedy.

Her nine year-old son Camden and one year-old son Maxwell both died in the crash, which happened shortly after they drove into a blizzard along Interstate 29.

It saw the truck rear-end the family’s Honda as it drove towards a ditch on the right-hand side of the road.

Police clearing both Curry, who was traveling to see family in Minnesota, as well as truck driver Michael Soyring of any wrongdoing, and said the fatal crash was a tragic accident.

Curry’s Honda Pilot was rear-ended by a truck driving behind it after she lost control of the car during a blizzard. Investigators say the truck’s driver took all reasonable precautions (Picture KUTV)

Investigators said Soyring was driving a well-maintained truck at a safe speed and with the necessary level of caution required, the Grand Forks Herald reported.

But now Curry has sued claiming that the driver of the semi should have left enough space between their vehicles for her to spin out of control and not be struck.

Woman shot by Labrador puppy as she sat in a car

Her lawsuit claims the truck driver ‘failed to exercise extreme caution by driving too fast for the weather conditions and not managing a reasonable distance for traffic ahead of him, which resulted in him crashing his tractor-trailer into Trista’s car.’

The accident left both Curry and her three year-old daughter seriously hurt, but both were ultimately able to overcome the injuries.

Curry and her children’s father Bryan Dean are also suing Soyring’s employer Pan-O-Gold baking, claiming that they should not have sent Soyring out in a job given the weather forecast for that day.

They have also claimed that Pan-O-Gold should have installed equipment on the truck that could have prevented it from striking Curry’s Honda.

Neither Soyring not Pan-O-Gold have commented on the lawsuit filed by Curry and Dean.
description: Trista Curry wants $10million from the driver of the truck who rear-ended her Honda, even though police investigators cleared him of any wrongdoing
